Borrower  Kingdom of Cambodia 
   
The Proposal  The  proposal  includes  (i)  a  program  cluster  under  the  Promoting 
Economic  Diversification  Program  (PED  Program)  for  $52.0  million, 
comprising three subprograms and reforms in macroeconomic stability, 
investment  climate,  and  trade  policy  and  facilitation;  (ii)  a  loan  of 
Special Drawing Rights 13,419,000  (equivalent to $20.0 million) for 
subprogram  1  of  the  program  cluster;  (iii)  a  $2.0  million  grant  for 
capacity development in sanitary and phytosanitary standards (SPS) 
management  systems  under  the  Program;  and  (iv)  an  $800,000 
technical assistance (TA) grant funded under the Technical Assistance 
Special Fund to strengthen private sector competitiveness.

The Program  The  core  objective  of  the  Government’s  Rectangular  Strategy  and 
Rationale  National  Strategic  Development  Plan  2006–2010  is  to  sustain  an 
economic  growth  rate  of  7–8%  per  year  with  poverty  reduction. 
Cambodia is also working toward a Millennium Development Goal of 
decreasing  its  poverty  incidence  rate  to  24%  by  2015.  The 
Government’s new initiative, a sector-wide approach (SWAp) to trade, 
aims to sustain economic growth by diversifying the country’s currently 
narrow economic base of garments, tourism, and construction. Private 
sector expansion is considered key to achieving these objectives.  
Cambodia’s poverty rate has declined in the past two decades from 
69.0% of the population living below $2 a day in 1996 to a projected 
50.5% in 2007. And, using the national poverty line based on daily 
calorie intake, the incidence of poverty has declined from 47% in 1994 
to 35% in 2004—a remarkable reduction considering this period’s rapid 
population growth. The decline was driven by economic expansion, 
opening  the  economy  to  trade  and  investment,  increased  rice 
production, and greater urbanization. In fact, it is common to see a 
sharp reduction in poverty once a country passes a per capita income 
threshold of $400, as Cambodia did in 2005. Achieving further poverty 
reduction will depend on sustaining economic growth rate of 7.5% per 
year over the medium term by diversifying the country’s economy and 
mobilizing additional fiscal resources to support long-term development 
and social spending objectives.

ii       
 
The country strategy and program (CSP) for 2005–2009 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) identifies private sector development as a 
key  priority  for  Cambodia.  It  emphasizes  that  ADB  will  help  the 
Government  to  improve  Cambodia’s  climate  for  private  sector 
development  through  technical  and  program  support  for  policy, 
institutional, and regulatory reform in key sectors. The CSP seeks to 
transform the agriculture sector from subsistence farming to a more 
commercial  orientation,  improve  basic  transport  and  power 
infrastructure,  strengthen  the  regulatory  regime  governing  financial 
institutions, develop small and medium-sized enterprises, and promote 
greater regional integration through ADB’s Greater Mekong Subregion 
Program. Linked to private sector development is good governance 
through promoting competition policy, which suggests that the reform 
agenda should be broad-based and focused on reducing transaction 
costs of doing business and improving predictability in the investment 
climate. Reforms supporting and strengthening the investment climate, 
competition policy, and better access to technology; completing the 
unfinished  trade  policy  regime;  and  enhancing  trade  facilitation 
measures  and  macroeconomic  stability  in  support  of  private  sector 
growth are also important for reducing transaction costs and expanding 
and diversifying the private sector.  
The Government has implemented a series of reform measures for the 
investment  climate  and  trade  aimed  at  reducing  the  cost  of  doing 
business  in  Cambodia,  including  customs  reforms  and  other  trade 
facilitation measures. Business climate reforms undertaken in the last 2 
years—many  accomplished  through  ADB’s  Small  and  Medium-Sized 
Enterprise Development Program—have also helped Cambodia to move 
up  15  places  in  the  International  Finance  Corporation’s  2008  Doing 
Business rankings. The Government is also committed to completing its 
World Trade Organization (WTO) commitments, which influence how 
Cambodia thinks about its business climate and trade policy over the 
medium term. At the same time, the Government has introduced more 
prudent fiscal policies to address the surge in domestic inflation caused 
by supply-side developments in global oil and food markets.  
   
Impact and  The impact of the PED Program will be an expanded and diversified 
Outcome  private sector. The outcome of the PED Program will be an improved 
business environment where the private sector operates efficiently and 
effectively. 
 
The PED Program includes a series of policy reforms that underpin the 
priorities of the National Strategic Development Plan 2006–2010  and 
its trade development agenda (SWAp) and are designed to (i) maintain 
macroeconomic stability necessary for private sector development and 
growth by continuing to make progress toward price stability through 
prudent  fiscal  policy;  (ii)  improve  the  investment  climate  by 
strengthening  investor  protection,  enhancing  the  environment  for 
competition and innovation, and institutionalizing a regulatory impact 
assessment within the Government and other policy reforms aimed at 
reducing transaction costs and risks in Cambodia; and (iii) improve

iii
trade policy and facilitation by continuing reforms to meet WTO legal 
requirements,  renewing  trade  policy  reforms,  and  enhancing  trade 
facilitation by strengthening SPS management systems and customs 
reforms. 
   
Financing Plan  A loan of $20 million equivalent from ADB’s Asian Development Fund 
(ADF) will be provided for subprogram 1 of the PED Program with terms 
of 24 years, an 8-year grace period, 1.0% interest rate during the grace 
period, and 1.5% during amortization and other terms and conditions 
set forth in the draft Loan Agreement. A capacity development project 
financed  by  a  $2  million  grant,  financed  under  ADB’s  ADF,  will  be 
provided to strengthen SPS management systems under the program 
cluster.  
   
Period and  The  PED  Program  implementation  period  is  from  June  2007  to 
Tranching  December  2012.  The  subprogram  1  period  is  from  June  2007  to 
December  2008,  with  a  single  tranche  loan  of  $20  million  to  be 
disbursed  under  subprogram  1  when  the  Government  has  met  the 
conditions  for  effectiveness.  Policy  measures  for  subprogram  2  are 
subject to revision and refinement following ADB’s assessment of the 
macroeconomic environment, changes in the external environment, and 
lessons  learned  from  implementing  subprogram  1.  Subprogram  2, 
currently estimated at $15 million, will be presented for ADB Board of 
Directors’  consideration  approximately  24  months  after  the 
effectiveness of subprogram 1, subject to the Government’s readiness 
to  continue  with  its  reform  agenda.  Subprogram  3,  also  currently 
estimated at $15 million, will be submitted for the Board’s consideration 
approximately  24  months  after  the  effectiveness  of  subprogram  2 
(about  October  2012),  subject  to  the  Government’s  readiness  to 
continue  with  its  reform  agenda.  The  starting  period  of  2007  was 
selected as it reflects the period of ADB’s engagement and dialogue 
with the Government on business climate reforms embedded in the 
PED Program.  
 
Counterpart Funds  The Government will use local currency counterpart funds generated by 
the loan proceeds to meet program expenditures and associated costs 
of reform and to help maintain current levels of social expenditure. 
   
Executing Agency   The Ministry of Commerce (MOC) will be responsible for coordinating 
the implementation of and sustaining the PED Program reform actions. 
   
Implementation  The Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy (MIME) and Ministry of 
Arrangements  Economy and Finance (MEF) are the implementing agencies. MOC will 
use its Private Sector Development Sub-Steering Committee on Trade 
Development and Trade-Related Investments (PSC), chaired by the 
minister of commerce and comprising senior officials from MIME and 
MEF to steer the program. The PSC will meet quarterly to monitor 
progress and oversee the implementation of the PED Program, and 
provide  guidance  and  direction  to  the  Executing  Agency  and 
implementing agencies.

Procurement   The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange 
costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items produced and procured

Program Benefits  The PED Program will provide the following benefits: 
and Beneficiaries   
(i)  Lowered transaction costs for businesses by reducing red tape, 
and  customs  reforms,  which  will  open  new  opportunities, 
increase trade, investment and productivity, boost the economy, 
increase incomes, and create jobs. The institutionalization of a 
regulatory  impact  assessment  will  improve  transparency  and 
accountability.  
(ii)  Strengthened  institutional  development  by  improving  the 
capabilities of the executing and implementing agencies to carry 
out  trade  and  competition  policy  analysis  with  the  aim  of 
upgrading the quality of policy and institutional processes for 
policy making. 
(iii)  Upgraded  agro-based  products  and  improved  market  access 
through effective SPS management systems. These systems 
will also increase food safety for the booming tourism sector and 
the population. 
(iv)  Improved  private  sector  capacity  in  SPS  and  other  related 
technologies through grant projects, which will also improve firm 
competitiveness. 
(v)  Maintained  stable  macroeconomy  through  continued  prudent 
fiscal policy. 
 
ADB staff estimates, based on simulations from the PED Program’s 
Cambodian  economy  model,  suggest  that  gains  from  PED  reforms 
could add 2.4% to the country’s gross domestic product, equivalent to 
about $200 million in 2007 prices. Employment is expected to rise by 
4.3% for males and 6.3% for females. Poverty is expected to fall by 
2.7%.  
   
Risks and  The assumptions underlying the PED Program include the following.  
Assumptions   
(i)  The economy will be able to maintain macroeconomic stability 
and withstand current external and domestic shocks.  
(ii)  The Government will stay on course with key business climate 
policy reform measures and fiscal consolidation.  
 
The risks include the following. 
 
(i)  In  transitional  economies,  maintaining  macroeconomic 
stability—as reflected, for example, in low inflation—is crucial for 
investor confidence and private sector growth. Cambodia will be 
particularly vulnerable to macroeconomic instability in 2008 and 
2009 due to the recent surge in inflation ignited by supply side 
developments in the global commodity and food markets, the 
global financial crisis that may slow foreign direct investment

v
inflows  to  Cambodia  and  the  expected  United  States  and 
European  economic  recessions  that  will  hurt  Cambodian 
merchandise  exports  to  these  markets.  In  addition,  over  the 
longer  term  Cambodia  will  face  emerging  fiscal  and 
macroeconomic  challenges  in  the  context  of  its  anticipated 
resource  boom  and  associated  volatile  commodity  prices. 
Recognizing these risks, the Government is undertaking fiscal 
and  monetary  policy  measures  to  maintain  macroeconomic 
stability,  implementing  programs  to  assist  the  poor  and 
vulnerable  from  these  shocks,  and  undertaking  measures  to 
strengthen  public  expenditure  management  using  assistance 
from its development partners, including ADB. 
(ii)  There may be weak coordination among Government agencies 
leading  to  delayed  compliance  with  policy  measures  and 
capacity development, but the adoption of the cluster mode for 
policy  lending  has  reduced  this  risk.  By  basing  financial 
assistance  and  TA  on  completed  actions  derived  from  the 
Government’s reform program, the PED Program strengthens 
the  Government’s  ownership  of  the  reform  program.  By 
including policy triggers for subsequent subprograms, the PED 
Program  offers  the  flexibility  needed  to  take  into  account 
changes in the external environment faced by Cambodia and 
emerging priority policy reforms. Moreover, the Government has 
taken  a  clear  stance  on  the  need  for  policy  adjustment  to 
diversify the economy, as articulated in its trade development 
agenda. 
(iii)  Agencies’ capacity to implement reforms may be constrained by 
resources  and  other  emerging  priorities.  The  PED  Program 
reduces this risk by limiting the policy triggers to a few high-
priority, high-impact policy reforms under the jurisdiction of MOC 
and MIME and by attaching TA to each policy trigger.  
(iv)  Vested  interests  will  resist some of  the  reforms.  Reforms  to 
customs  and  institutionalization  of  economic  governance 
reforms (e.g., regulatory impact assessment) are likely to be 
lengthy. However, several factors mitigate these risks. First, the 
PED  Program’s  strategic  approach  is  to  focus  efforts  on 
supporting the Government’s initiatives and building on existing 
institutions. Second, reforms will focus on areas with political will 
and some measure of capacity. This has been demonstrated by 
MOC, which has championed trade reforms and lead the WTO 
accession process.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
Program to the Kingdom of Cambodia for Promoting Economic Diversification Program (PED 
Program)  for  $52.0  million  comprising  three  subprograms,  (ii)  a  proposed  loan  of  Special 
Drawing Rights 13,419,000 (equivalent to $20.0 million) for subprogram 1 of the Program, and 
(iii)  a  proposed  grant  of  $2  million  for  capacity  development  to  strengthen  sanitary  and 
phytosanitary  standards  (SPS)  management  systems.  This  report  also  describes  proposed 
technical assistance (TA) for improving competitiveness of the private sector. If the Board 
approves the proposed loan and grant, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the 
Board, will approve the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM AND MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
A.  Cambodia’s Socioeconomic Development Plan 
2.  In 2004, the Government announced its long-term development strategy—known as the 
Rectangular Strategy—that focuses on better governance and institutional building, including 
anticorruption measures and public administrative reforms. One component concentrates on 
promoting  economic  growth  through  agriculture,  infrastructure,  and  private  sector  growth; 
employment;  and  human  resource  development.  In  2006,  the  Government  announced  its 
second  5-year  National  Strategic  Development  Plan  2006–2010  (NSDP),1 which  aims  to 
operationalize  the  Rectangular  Strategy  and  achieve  interim  targets  in  2010.  While  the 
Rectangular  Strategy  focuses  more  on  the  identification  of  crosscutting  policy  issues  and 
strategies  to  ensure  a  more  integrated  development  policy  framework,  the  NSDP 
operationalizes it with programs, projects, and development targets (Figure 1).  
 
3.  To help implement the priorities and programs of the Rectangular Strategy and the 
NSDP,  the  Government  has  adopted  several  sector  strategies,  most  with  time  bound 
implementation  plans  and  clearly  defined  ministerial  responsibilities,  of  which  some  are 
supported  by  ADB  sector  programs  and  TA.  The  anchor  for  the  Promoting  Economic 
Diversification Program is the Government’s trade development agenda known as its sector-
wide approach (SWAp) to trade, underpinned by a diagnostic trade integration study (DTIS) that 
was launched by the Ministry of Commerce (MOC) on 5 December 2007. The SWAp supports 
expanding  the  private sector  by  improving  both  foreign and  domestic  trade  by  developing 
efficient backward links in the economy.2 It identifies 19 products as pilot projects for catalyzing 
a broad-based reform agenda, while at the same time recognizing the necessity for specific 
reforms and capacity-building initiatives in some sectors. The SWAp is a new initiative built on 
three pillars: (i) crosscutting issues (SPS and trade policy formulation), (ii) capacity development 
in trade, and (iii) product development (i.e., the 19 products). The SWAp is coordinated by MOC 
through the Private Sector Development Sub-Steering Committee on Trade Development and 
Trade-related Investments (PSC) with the aim of mainstreaming trade in economic policy. The 
minister of commerce chairs the committee.

4.  The Private Sector Development Steering Committee has sub-steering committees on 
manufacturing and small and medium-sized enterprise development, investment climate and 
private participation in infrastructure, and trade development and trade-related investments 
(PSC). It provides the opportunity for an ongoing dialogue—involving the Government, private 
sector, international development partners, civil society, and the academic community— on the 
economic reform agenda and ways donors can assist with implementation. The PSC also allows 
development partners to enhance their policy engagement with the Government and to drive 
forward  the  NSDP  and  SWAp.3 The  PED  Program  will  be  anchored  in  the  SWAp  and 
coordinated by MOC through the PSC, which avoids the establishment of an additional forum. 
The PED Program will focus on the following core policy areas identified in the SWAp and the

5.  The PED Program will support the Government’s private sector development agenda,

6.  Key features of the PED Program include (i) a series of single-tranche operations with a

III.  THE SECTOR 
A.  Review of the Economy, Investment Climate, and Poverty 
 
15.  Sustained Economic Growth in 2007. After a decade of respectable growth averaging 
7.5%, Cambodia’s economy accelerated more than 10% in 2004 and sustained double-digit 
expansion through 2007 (Table 1). This robust growth was driven by industry with particularly 
strong performances by construction and garment making. Services were also strong, especially 
tourism, banking, and real estate.  Agriculture, which tends to be volatile, averaged 6% growth 
during this period. However, exports soon slowed to an 11% growth rate in 2007, down from 
27% in 2006, primarily due to a sharp slowdown in garment exports. This slowdown continued 
into 2008, with garment exports rising by 5%, the lowest rate of increase in several years. Two 
million people visited Cambodia in 2007—a record—generating an estimated $1.1 billion in 
revenue and helping to fuel a construction boom in Siem Reap and other destinations. Visitor 
arrivals are estimated to exceed two million in 2008. Foreign investment almost doubled in 2007 
over 2006 levels ($900 million versus $475 million) with a substantial proportion reportedly 
invested in real estate, contributing to the property price boom. Several major international 
corporations in agroprocessing and chemicals have set up representative offices in Cambodia, 
indicative of some investment diversification beginning to occur. 
 
16.  Inflation Surged at the End of 2007. Cambodia has achieved rapid economic growth 
with modest rates of inflation. Inflation averaged just below 4% per year between 2001 and early

7
2007, anchored by the United States (US) dollar and low US inflation.6 However, by the third 
quarter of 2007, domestic inflation began to surge, rising from 6.4% in September to 10.8% in 
December 2007 and to 25.7% by May 2008. Inflation pressure has begun to ease since June 
with inflation in July at 22.3% on a year-on-year basis. Domestic inflation was ignited on the 
supply  side  by  sharply  higher  global  prices  for  petroleum  and  food  earlier  this  year,  and 
exacerbated by the depreciation of the US dollar against Cambodia’s major trading partners in 
2007. At the same time, there had been signs that the economy was overheating—economic 
growth in 2007 was beginning to diverge above its potential growth path; private sector credit 
and broad money supply have expanded at unprecedented rates; and at the end of 2007, the 
broad monetary aggregates were about 60% higher than levels 1 year before. Furthermore, 
excess liquidity in the banking system is estimated at over 30% of deposits. Unprecedented 
monetary  aggregate  growth  rates  in  a  hugely  inflationary  environment  increased  risks  of 
second-round  inflationary  effects  and  macroeconomic  instability.  The  National  Bank  of 
Cambodia has responded by doubling the reserve requirement from 8% to 16% and relaxing 
capital outflows by allowing, upon verification, commercial banks to invest their surplus reserves 
abroad where they can earn a higher rate of return. Growth in monetary aggregates slowed to 
about 43% in the first semester of 2008 over the same period in 2007, indicating a lessening of 
inflationary pressures. 
 
17.  Prudent Fiscal Policy. The effectiveness of monetary policy is limited in a dollarized 
economy like Cambodia, and must be supplemented with an appropriate fiscal policy stance—
for example, accumulating domestic budget surpluses when strong inflation pressures emerge 
or when the economy shows signs of overheating. Accordingly, Cambodia’s fiscal policy has 
tightened in recent years. The overall deficit narrowed significantly from over 7.0% of the gross 
domestic product (GDP) in 2002 to 2.8% in 2007, with improvement reflected in the current 
balance  surplus,  i.e.,  current  expenditures  less  current  revenues.  Total  revenues  have 
expanded steadily in relation to the GDP, with gains from all major tax components. On the side 
of expenditures, a period of consolidation ended in 2005; the following 2 years witnessed an 
increase in spending of almost 1.5% of the GDP with both current and capital expenditures 
rising. The approved 2008 budget is relatively expansionary on paper as it projects a fall in the 
current budget surplus from 3% in 2007 to 1% in 2008 and a small drop in government deposits 
at the National Bank of Cambodia. However, during the first half of 2008, government deposits 
rose over 30% and the annualized budget deficit fell to 0.4% of the GDP, suggesting that the 
actual outturn may be less expansionary (para. 20).  
 
18.  Challenges to Sustaining Economic Growth in 2008 and 2009. Cambodia’s economy 
in 2008 and 2009 will be vulnerable to three adverse developments in the external environment: 
(i) the financial global crisis may slow foreign direct investment inflows to Cambodia as investors 
wind back global investments due to the credit crunch in developed markets; (ii) the expected 
contraction in the US and European economies in 2009 will affect the demand for Cambodian 
exports and visitors to Cambodia; and (iii) the unexpected surge in international food and oil 
prices earlier this year, contributed to higher domestic inflation in 2008, which is expected to 
slow household consumption and economic growth. ADB staff forecasts on economic growth 
suggest that the increases in oil prices may cut the economic growth rate by as much as 3% in 
2008 due to Cambodia’s higher fuel content in production costs. Economic growth could be 
lower in 2009. A recent International Monetary Fund report assessed the impact of global

19.  Using the national poverty line based on a 2000 calorie intake per person, the incidence 
of poverty in Cambodia has declined from 47% in 1994 to 35% in 2004. Using the $2-a-day 
poverty line, the incidence of poverty is estimated to have fallen from 69.0% in 1996 to a 
projected 50.5% in 2007.8 This compares with 62.3% of the population living below $2 a day in 
the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, 32.9% in Viet Nam, 45.2% in Indonesia, and 44.9% in 
the Philippines. Factors contributing to this remarkable reduction in poverty include sustained 
per capita income expansion, with poverty sharply falling after per capita income surpassed 
$400 in 2005; greater labor mobility between rural and urban areas (and urbanization); higher 
rice production; private sector expansion; and improvements in market access internally and to 
neighboring countries. Poverty in Cambodia is primarily a rural phenomenon, with the official 
rural  poverty  rate  at  39%  of  the  rural  population.  Moreover,  there  are  significant  regional 
disparities in the incidence of poverty in Cambodia, with very low rates of poverty recorded in 
regions with higher per capita incomes (e.g., Phnom Penh, Kandal province, and Sihanoukville) 
and high rates in those with low per capita incomes (e.g., Kampong Speu, Kampong Thum, and 
Siem Reap). At the same time, income inequality has increased, as measured by the Gini 
coefficient, from 0.35% in 1994 to 0.40% in 2004. The widening income gap between rural and 
urban  populations  and  within  rural  populations  contributed  to  this  increase.  Rising  income 
inequality is typical in the earlier stages of development in a low-income but fast-growing 
economy  driven  by  urban  economic  growth.  ADB  staff  poverty  simulations  indicate  that 
Cambodia could reach its Millennium Development Goal national poverty target of 24% of the 
population by 2015, depending on achieving an economic growth rate of 7.5% (or 5% per capita 
income growth) per year from 2008 to 2015, low inflation in the range of 3% per year, and stable 
income distribution. However, these variables have deteriorated in 2008, thus increasing the 
probability that Cambodia may fall short of its target.  
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
20.  The challenge for Cambodia is to sustain a high economic growth rate, accelerate the 
creation of productive jobs, and continue poverty reduction—difficult tasks with half of the 
population under age 20 years and more than 85% employed in the informal sector. The 
Government recognizes that the key to sustaining high economic growth and poverty reduction 
is to diversify the sources of growth from its currently narrow base in construction, garment 
making, and tourism (Figure 3), which requires further reforms to improve competitiveness at all 
levels of the supply chain (Appendix 4). Sustaining high economic growth over the longer term 
will require export diversification as well as building links between agriculture and the modern 
sector. The Government believes that the private sector will be central to its diversification 
strategy. Reforms to enhance competitiveness will require macroeconomic stability, institutional 
reforms to investment climate, competition policy, and enhanced trade facilitation measures.

1.  Macroeconomic Stability for Private Sector Growth 
21.  A critical short-term issue affecting private sector growth is inflation. Over the 
longer term, a potential challenge for the Government will be to improve conditions for growth of 
the nonresource private sector in the event that Cambodia’s oil reserves are proven to be large 
and lead to a substantial resource boom. Integral to maintaining this growth is macroeconomic 
stability. 
 
22.  Macroeconomic stability is being tested by the surge in domestic inflation that was 
initially ignited by global food and oil price surges, and most recently, the possibility of emerging 
second-round effects. Authorities will need to supplement the recent tightening of monetary 
policy with tighter fiscal policy to slow aggregate demand and inflation pressures. This will 
require continuing to operate sizeable current budget surpluses and accumulating government 
deposits at the National Bank of Cambodia above its current level of 6% of GDP for 2008 
(Figure 4). 
 
23.  A Future Oil Boom Could Impact Private Sector Development. The nonresource 
private sector will be influenced by future developments in the resource sector. While there are 
no definitive figures on Cambodia’s proven oil reserves and timing of future production contracts 
and commercial operations, the Government anticipates significant future revenues from oil 
extraction  and  other  investments  in  the  mining  sector  in  the  form  of  taxes,  royalties,  and 
dividends.  Revenue  flows  would  provide  fiscal  space  and  a  tremendous  opportunity  for 
Cambodia to finance its priority development goals, raise the per capita income, and reduce 
poverty, as earlier resource booms have done in Indonesia and Botswana. At the same, a 
resource boom of long duration can affect competitiveness of the nonresource tradable goods 
sectors (agriculture and garments) if it leads to an excessive appreciation of the real exchange 
rate––i.e., where the appreciation cannot be justified on the basis of economy-wide productivity 
growth  and  investment.  There  are  important  lessons  to  be  learned  from  Indonesia  and 
Botswana in maintaining private sector growth when there is an oil boom, including maintaining 
fiscal discipline, smoothing out expenditures to avoid excessively inflationary effects of resource 
revenues flows in the economy, and reforming the business climate and investments to raise

24.  The Government is acutely aware of the necessity for a stable macroeconomy for private 
sector development. In this context, the Government is operating a prudent fiscal policy, and it 
has tightened monetary policy and relaxed restrictions on banks holding deposits offshore to 
reduce excess liquidity in the domestic banking system. However, there are challenges to 
improving fiscal sustainability over the medium term. Cambodia has one of the lowest tax 
revenue to GDP ratios (about 10–11%) among low-income countries, partly because of the 
dominance of the subsistence agriculture sector in the economy. Revenue management is 
challenged by (i) the dual tax system, with the estimated tax system undermining revenue 
mobilization;  (ii)  nontransparent  fiscal  incentives  regime;  and  (iii)  weak  tax  administration. 
Recent improvements in tax collection have helped address part of the problem of revenue 
mobilization, with revenues rising by 42% in 2007.  
 
2.  Investment Climate 
25.  Investment Growth is concentrated in a few sectors. While investment in Cambodia 
has shown robust growth in the last 4 years—averaging 13% per year since 2003—and the 
investment  to  GDP  rate  has  increased  from  19%  in  2003  to  21%  in  2007,  it  has  been 
concentrated in a few sectors such as real estate, tourism, and until recently, garments. This 
reflects the concentrated economic base of the modern economy where these three sectors 
alone  account  for  42%  of  nonagriculture  GDP  (Figure  3).  While  there  has  been  some 
diversification in the economy, much needs to be done to facilitate greater diversification and to 
achieve a higher investment rate.

uncertainty, inadequate skills of the labor force, limited access to technology and low innovative 
activity, and costly trade facilitation. Results from the World Bank’s 2007 Investment Climate

supplemented  with  bilateral  investment  agreements  that  elaborate  investor  guarantees, 
protection, and dispute resolution. Cambodia joined the World Bank’s Multilateral Investment 
Guarantee  Agency  in  2000.  It  has  some  20  bilateral  investment  agreements  with  trading 
partners and is negotiating additional agreements with Algeria, Austria, Egypt, Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic, Libya, Myanmar, Russian Federation, Ukraine, and United Kingdom.11

28.  Competition  Policy.  In  general,  Cambodia  is  a  competitive  economy  where  many 
anticompetitive  issues  that  characterize  most  other  Southeast  Asian  economies  are  less 
relevant. For example, Cambodia is relatively open at the border. Most major nontariff barriers 
have been eliminated and tariffs reformed, albeit they are still relatively high in some areas. 
Cambodia also does not have a large state enterprise sector, normally a major source of 
anticompetitive behavior in developing economies. However, as the economy expands and 
becomes more sophisticated, it will be necessary to ensure competition in industries typically 
vulnerable to anticompetitive behavior, mainly traditional nontradable services, such as utilities. 
A  pragmatic  approach  to  competition  policy  would  be  to  establish  a  policy  framework  for 
competition focusing on open tariff and other trade policies, as well as deregulatory rules and 
guidelines overseen by independent regulatory bodies to ensure contestable utility markets, and 
establishing a RIA within the Government to ensure regulations are not anticompetitive and 
licensing  does  not  disadvantage  existing  or  potential  competitors  (i.e.,  competitive  neutral 
regulations). Regional neighbors have implemented competition policies; Indonesia’s approach 
has been to start with trade reforms, deregulation, and then privatization. At the later stages of 
implementation, the Government of Indonesia introduced a competition law and commission in 
1999. The commission’s approach has been pragmatic, and its efforts have helped trigger 
deregulation  in  a  few  sectors  (e.g.,  domestic  airlines).  However,  its  capacity  to  carry 
sophisticated economic analysis required for demonstrating anticompetitive behavior has been 
limited.  
 
29.  Excessive Red Tape and Licensing. In Cambodia, investors are concerned about red 
tape and associated informal payments. Line ministries are not required to assess the cost of 
compliance with regulations for the business community or individuals or to assess whether the 
regulations  may  hurt  competition.  Therefore,  regulatory  compliance  costs  imposed  on  the

does have a legislative review process carried out by the Economic, Social Affairs and Culture

that the review must be institutionalized within line ministries, and an oversight agency is 
needed to advocate and monitor RIA. To do so requires a sequencing of institutional reforms

3.  Trade Policy and Facilitation 
30.  Cambodia has made considerable progress in establishing a modern trade regime. 
Under the trading system adopted in the early 1980s, the level and composition of trade was 
effectively  controlled  through  quantitative  restrictions  and  state-owned  trading  companies. 
Tariffs and trade taxes played little or no role other than as a means to collect revenue. In the 
late 1980s, however, a process of market-oriented reforms began. The state monopoly on 
foreign  trade  was  abolished  in  1987,  and  a  1989  foreign  investment  law  allowed  private 
companies to engage in foreign trade. In 1993, trade policies were greatly liberalized resulting in 
few binding quantitative restrictions and nonprohibitive tax rates on imports and exports. In 2001, 
the  tariff  structure  was  substantially  rationalized  and  liberalized  when  the  maximum  
most-favored  nation  rate  was  reduced  to  35%.  In  2004,  Cambodia  acceded  to  WTO  and 
committed to implementing legal reforms, including enacting over 25 different laws. However, no 
significant most-favored nation tariff reforms have occurred since 2001, although Cambodia has 
continued  to  implement  preferential  tariff  reductions  for its  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations  (ASEAN)  trading  partners  under  the  common  external  preferential  tariff.  Its  trade 
reforms have focused on trade facilitation measures, and preferential tariff reductions have 
widened the tax wedge with most-favored nation rates. Going forward, it is opportune time to 
reassess the tariff structure with a view to toward reducing the maximum rate of 35% to lower 
the tax wedge. The timing of tariff reductions will be subject to tax revenue  sustainability 
assessments, as customs revenue collection accounts for about 25% of the Government’s 
budget revenues.

31.  WTO Commitments. The Government continues to implement economic, trade, and 
legal commitments as agreed under its WTO accession. However, it has not yet completed 
implementation of its customs transaction valuation commitments, which are due by 2009. Legal 
and compliance notifications to WTO are also backlogged, including technical barriers to trade, 
SPS, and other potential nontariff barriers. Therefore, MOC established the Department of 
Notification and Legal Compliance (WTO Department) as the Government’s focal point for 
complying with WTO notification requirements.12 While the Government considers completing 
WTO  commitments  important  for  its  integration  efforts,  it  must  strengthen  the  capacity  to 
implement required policy reforms and to establish compliance notification procedures across 
relevant agencies. This requires significant capacity development within the WTO Department 
as well as staff training. An immediate task will be to prioritize future work priorities of the 
various offices, including assigning each office clear responsibilities, especially in light of current 
inadequate staff numbers, which are unlikely to be substantially raised. The WTO Department 
currently  is  “top  heavy”  with  nine  staff  members,  including  the  director  and  three  deputy 
directors; the position of deputy director of the Legal Compliance Office is currently vacant. The 
WTO Office has two staff members and the Notification and Administration Office one staff 
member; the other two offices, including the increasingly important Services Negotiation Office, 
effectively  have  no  staff  members.  This  may  also  be  an  opportune  time  for  Cambodia  to 
undertake its first WTO trade policy review, an obligation that would provide a desirable stock 
take on its trade-related policy regime; increase transparency; and inform WTO partners of its 
trade-related developments, any major policy obstacles, and TA needs.

lead agency in WTO negotiations, and inspects imports through Camcontrol. While MOC has a 
foreign trade directorate, of which the new WTO Department is part, it lacks the resources 
needed to conduct adequate trade policy analysis essential for supporting further trade reforms 
and to participate in WTO.13 At the same time, several government agencies are involved in

development of its conformity assessment body and its ISO accreditation; (ii) improving SPS 
related to food and water; and (iii) developing effective management systems such as further 
upgrading of laboratories (at MAFF, MIME, and Camcontrol), assisting with these laboratories’

development  and  economic  diversification  is  a  long-term  effort  requiring  a  
longer-term policy perspective. The adoption of the SWAp to trade and DTIS 
meant that the Government has a set of long-term objectives that guide and 
shape medium-term policy design and implementation. The close consultative 
process  involving  the  Government,  ADB,  and  other  development  partners 
strengthened  the  Government’s  ownership  and  increased  the  potential  for

(ii)  Flexibility in design. Private sector reforms involving the investment climate and

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
38.  The impact of the PED Program will be an expanded and diversified private sector. The 
outcome of the PED Program will be an improved business environment where the private 
sector operates efficiently and effectively. 
 
39.  The PED Program includes a series of policy reforms that underpin the priorities of the 
NSDP and the SWAp and are designed to accomplish the following:  
 
(i)  maintain macroeconomic stability necessary for private sector development and 
growth by continuing to make progress toward price stability through prudent 
fiscal policy, as price instability in a transitional economic can inhibit private 
sector growth; 
(ii)  improve the investment climate by strengthening investor protection, enhancing 
the environment for competition and innovation, and institutionalizing a RIA within 
the Government and other policy reforms aimed at reducing transaction costs 
and risks in Cambodia; and 
(iii)  improve trade policy and facilitation by continuing reforms to meet WTO legal 
requirements, renewing trade policy reforms, and enhancing trade facilitation by 
strengthening SPS management systems and customs reforms.

framework to align with the Government’s SWAp to trade. A TA project and a policy advisory TA

Program  period.  Consideration  of  subprograms  2  and  3  and  will  depend  on  satisfactory 
accomplishment of policy triggers. TA for subprograms 2 and 3 will also depend on satisfactory

1.  Subprogram 1, Core Area 1: Macroeconomic Stability in Support of Private 
Sector Development 
42.  Subprogram  1  acknowledges  that  Cambodia  has  made  progress  in  maintaining 
macroeconomic stability through tightening its fiscal policy and implementing measures to lower 
aggregate demand to contain inflation in 2008. 
 
43.  The increase in the public budget surplus from 1.2% of the GDP in 2006 to 3.2% in 2007 
and maintaining a sizeable surplus in 2008 were major achievements and contributed to an 
appropriate macroeconomic policy response to the surge in domestic inflation and signs of 
overheating of the economy in 2007. The appropriate fiscal stance is reflected in the continued 
accumulation of government deposits at the National Bank of Cambodia by over 30% in the 9 
months of 2008 over 2007 levels. The increase in the budget surplus was aided by an increase 
in revenue collection, amounting to 42% in 2007 over 2006 levels, which was achieved through 
greater income tax as well as improved tax collections. The continual reduction in the year-end 
debt  level  from  27%  in  2005  to  25%  in  2006  and  24%  in  2007  further  improves  debt 
sustainability.  
 
2.  Subprogram 1, Core Area 2: Investment Climate 
44.  Subprogram  1  supports  the  Government’s  agenda  to  improve  the  regulatory 
environment  for  investments  and  private  sector  growth.  The  main  objective  is  to  diversify 
investment in the economy. Reform areas of critical significance include implementing action 
plans  for  regulatory  impact  assessments,  reducing  the  cost  of  enterprise  registration,  and

streamline red tape by assisting with the establishment of an institutionalized RIA in the medium

the PED Program to support the implementation of the action plan, including developing the 
checklists and training on cost compliance analysis. TA will be provided to MOC to develop an 
action plan and to assist OBSESS in strengthening its capacity in subsequent subprograms. 
 
46.  Reduce Registration Costs. In 2007, MOC reduced the cost of enterprise registration

59.  Impact and Outcomes of the Program. By the end of 2012, the PED Program is 
expected to have improved Cambodia’s macroeconomic stability through prudent fiscal policy; 
increased investment and economic diversification through lowered regulatory compliance costs 
and  better  investor  protection;  increased  exports  and  diversification  of  products  through 
improved SPS management systems and private sector access to SPSs; reduced customs 
trade facilitation costs; and promoting competition. The Program also will have strengthened the 
SPS management system, increased the Government’s capacity to assess trade policy for 
Cambodia, addressed the backlog in WTO compliance and legal notifications, and improved 
SME access to SPS technology.

D.  Important Features 
 
61.  The PED Program has some distinct and innovative features. First, the Government has 
demonstrated ownership by formulating a consistent and well-sequenced policy framework for 
private sector reforms over the medium term, as articulated in its SWAp to trade and DTIS. 
Second, designed as a program cluster with subsequent subprograms linked by triggers within a 
medium-term  framework,  the  PED  Program  encourages  continuous  engagement  by 
development partners over the medium-term. Third, the central feature of the PED Program is 
capacity development, which is addressed through TA, projects and anchoring the program to 
the Government’s SWAp to trade. Fourth, the PED Program uses TA projects and grants to 
strengthen capacity to enhance private sector competitiveness, which are linked to satisfactory 
accomplishment  of  policy  triggers  or  milestones  (Appendix  8).  This  ensures  government 
ownership and an appropriate policy environment for implementation of the TA.

62.  The Government has requested a loan of $20 million equivalent from ADB’s Special

and rents resulting from customs reforms, (ii) further reductions in the revenues of the relevant

delivery of services to exporters and suppliers to the domestic market. Improved SPS, and

project, and identify issues and challenges. The EA and ADB will conduct a midterm review 
covering a comprehensive assessment of achievements against the SPS project’s expected

for the successful completion of the SPS project.

VI.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
87.  In connection with the PED Program, a policy and advisory TA grant for enhancing 
private  sector  competitiveness  is  proposed  to  support  capacity  development  and 
implementation of the policy triggers under subprogram 2. The TA is estimated at a cost of 
$960,000, of which $800,000 is proposed to be financed by the Technical Assistance Special 
Fund (Appendix 9). 
 
88.  The TA will support the implementation of the triggers for subprogram 2 and provide the 
Government with timely policy advice on a demand basis. The objective of the TA is to assist 
the Government in finding practical solutions to address these issues, as well as to deepen the 
Government’s agenda in the investment and trade area under the PED Program. It has five 
components.  Component  1  will  support  trade  policy  and  competition  policy  capacity 
development at MOC, including assisting in capacity development at the new WTO Department, 
developing  trade  remedies,  developing  a  competition  policy  framework,  and  facilitating  its 
adoption. This will include undertaking a series of case studies on anticompetitive practices. 
This component will also assist MOC with rolling out its enterprise registry to selected provinces. 
Component 2 will support MOC and MIME to implement action plans for regulatory review and 
strengthen capacity at OBSESS. Component 3 will assist MIME to develop a technology policy 
framework.  Component  4  will  support  MEF  to  develop  frameworks  for  double  taxation 
agreements and advocating their adoption as part of the Government’s investment promotion 
regime. Component 5 will work with the Customs & Excise Department to strengthen capacity at 
the risk management unit and to undertake a study on Cambodia’s readiness to join the Kyoto 
Convention. MOC will be the EA for the TA. The TA budget and implementation arrangements 
are in Appendix 9. The terms of references are in Supplementary Appendix 2.  
 
VII.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Expected Impacts 
 
89.  The key benefits expected from the PED Program are: 
 
(i)  Lowered transaction costs for businesses because of reduction in red tape and 
customs reforms which will open new opportunities, increase trade, investment 
and productivity, boost the economy, increase incomes, and create jobs.  
(ii)  Strengthened institutional development by improving the capabilities of the EA 
and  IAs  to  carry  out  trade  and  competition  policy  analysis  with  the  aim  of 
upgrading the quality of policy and institutional processes for policy making. 
(iii)  Upgraded agro-based products and improved market access through effective 
SPS management systems. It will also improve food safety for the booming 
tourism sector and contribute to improved food safety for the population. 
(iv)  Improved private sector capacity in SPS and related technologies through grant 
projects, which will also improve firm competitiveness. 
(v)  Maintained a stable macroeconomy through prudent fiscal policy. 
 
B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
90.  The PED Program is subject to the following risks.  
 
(i)  In transition economies, maintaining macroeconomic stability––as reflected, for 
example, in low inflation––is crucial for investor confidence and private sector

33
growth. Cambodia will be particularly vulnerable to macroeconomic instability in 
2008 and 2009 due to the recent surge in inflation that may slow household 
spending,  the  global  financial  crisis  that  may  slow  foreign  direct  investment 
inflows to Cambodia, and the expected United States and European economic 
recessions that will hurt Cambodian merchandise exports to these markets.  
(ii)  There  may  be  weak  coordination  among  government  agencies,  leading  to 
delayed compliance with policy measures and capacity development. By basing 
financial assistance and TA on completed actions derived from the Government’s 
reform program, the PED Program strengthens the Government’s ownership. By 
including policy triggers for subsequent subprograms, the PED Program offers 
the flexibility needed to take into account changes in the external environment 
faced  by  Cambodia  and  emerging  priority  policy  reforms.  Moreover,  the 
Government  has  taken  a  clear  stance  on  the  need  for  policy  adjustment  to 
diversify the economy, as articulated in its SWAp to trade and DTIS.  
(iii)  The capacity of agencies to implement reforms may be constrained by resources 
and other emerging priorities. The PED Program reduces this risk by limiting the 
policy  triggers  to  a  few  high-priority,  high-impact  policy  reforms  under  the 
jurisdiction of MOC and MIME and by attaching TA to each trigger and the 
capacity development grant to strengthened SPS management systems.  
(iv)  Vested  interests  will  resist  some  of  the  reforms.  Reforms  to  customs  and 
institutionalization  of  economic  governance  reforms––i.e.,  regulatory  impact 
assessments––are  likely  to  be  drawn-out.  However,  several  factors  mitigate 
these risks. First, the PED strategic approach is to focus efforts on supporting the 
Government’s initiatives and building on existing institutions. Second, reforms will 
focus on areas with political will and some measure of capacity. This has been 
demonstrated by MOC, which has championed trade reforms, lead the WTO 
accession  process,  and  now  leads  the  trade development  agenda  (e.g.,  the 
SWAp to trade).

A.  Background 
 
2.  Cambodia’s economic performance has been impressive over the last 5 years. From 
2003 to 2007, economic growth averaged around 10.5%, and the gross domestic product (GDP) 
per capita increased by over 70% to $598. Based on the $2-per-day poverty line, poverty 
incidence declined by 1.6 million persons (18%) during the same period (Figure A4.1), and 
poverty  reduction  accelerated  after  2004  when  per  capita  income  surpassed  $400.  The 
economic  growth  has  been  supported  mainly  by  the  manufacturing,  construction,  and  the 
service sectors. The manufacturing sector was driven by garment making, mainly for export, 
which  made  the  industry  vulnerable  to  external  shocks.  The  service  sector  depends  on  
tourism-related activities; international visitors to Cambodia continue to increase, with over 2 
million people traveling in 2007, generating over $1 billion in revenues. More recently, the 
construction sector has become fast-growing, owing to large-scale public infrastructure projects 
and an increasing demand for residential properties. Several foreign investors have also moved 
forward with major property development projects. 
 
3.  Cambodia’s economy has undergone significant structural transformation since 1990, 
but remains narrowly based, with three sectors—garments, construction, and tourist-related 
services—accounting for 42% of GDP in 2007. The share of industry increased from 11% of 
GDP in 1990 to 25% in 2007, while the agriculture sector share declined from 5% to 30% during 
the same period and the service sector expanded from 33% to 39% (Figure A4.1). Cambodia’s 
structural transformation has been dependent on a few products. Unrestricted access to the 
United  States  (US)  and  European  Commission  markets  from  the  early  to  late  1990s  
jump-started  the  garment  sector,  and  preferential  access  (or  less  restrictive  arrangement 
relative to other countries) to the US market after 1999 also drove this growth. The garment 
sector accounts for 70% of the manufacturing sector (12% of GDP) and 70% of Cambodia’s 
export revenue. The ancient temples at Angkor have attracted a continuous flow of international 
tourists and became the catalyst of growth for the service sector (Figure A4.1). While the 
garment and service sectors have attracted significant foreign direct investment in the past, 
sizeable foreign direct investment has recently moved to the construction sector (Figure A4.1). 
This pattern of structural change is expected as an economy grows and develops; resources 
move  from  low-productivity  activities  in  subsistence  agriculture  and  traditional  services  to 
higher-productivity  activities  in  industry  and  other  modern  services.  This  process,  and  the 
associated  rural-to-urban  migration  that  occurs  with  this  transformation,  contributes  to  a 
reduction in poverty.

Cambodia and accounts for substantial employment. According to latest available data from

estimate the actual number of SMEs, especially the very small ones. Based on available data,

industrial establishments. In the past, many Cambodian SMEs were unregistered, primarily 
because  of  the  high  cost,  cumbersome  procedures,  and  a  lack  of  transparency  in  the

8.  Transaction costs for doing business in Cambodia are high, but much lower than they 
once were. Cambodia continues to rank low in several international surveys of competitiveness 
due  to  high  transaction  costs  in  the  regulatory  environment,  trade  facilitation,  and  an 
undeveloped logistics sector. Figure A4.3 shows that trade facilitation costs in Cambodia are 
high on a regional and international comparison. The 2007 World Bank Investment Climate 
Survey  of  enterprises  reported  several  major  constraints  in  Cambodia,  including 
macroeconomic instability, energy costs, regulation, labor skills, anticompetitive and informal 
practices.  
 
9.  Business surveys in Cambodia, as well as a regional comparison, consistently indicate 
electricity cost is a barrier to improved business competitiveness. The average tariff is about 
$0.146 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) in Phnom Penh, and $0.25–0.80/kWh in remote areas. The

efficiency. Several development partners are assisting the government with expansion of the

MACROECONOMIC ASSESSMENT AND DEBT SUSTAINABILITY ASSESSMENT 
 
1.  This assessment provides a summary of developments in macroeconomic policy. It also 
presents a summary assessment of debt sustainability. 
 
2.  The immediate pressing issue is the acceleration in domestic price inflation and its 
potential impact on growth conditions in Cambodia and its poor. While much has been done to 
put fiscal policy on a sound path, critical issues that face the Government over the medium term 
include further efforts to raise revenues, improving efficiency in public expenditure management, 
strengthening debt management systems, and managing potential oil revenues. Important risks 
include weaker external demand and heightened regional competition for Cambodia’s main 
export commodities. The Government has outlined measures to address inflation and has a 
fiscal sustainability strategy supported by Asian Development Bank (ADB) programs.   
 
A.  Inflation 
 
3.  After remaining in single digits in the previous years, inflation rose significantly starting in 
September  2007.  From  an  average  of  3.9%  from  December  2002  to  2006,  year-on-year 
consumer price inflation1 surged to 10.8% in December 2007 and 25.7% in May 2008. The data 
suggest that inflation pressures have eased since June, but inflation remained high at 22.3% in 
July. 
 
4.  The sharp increase in inflation reflects both external shocks and domestic pressures. 
Available data suggests that three factors contributed to Cambodia’s surge in domestic inflation 
since the fourth quarter of 2007. First, the surge in global oil and food prices quickly transmitted 
to domestic food inflation [Figure A5.1(i) and (ii)]. Second, the depreciation of the riel and the 
United States (US) dollar against the currencies of Cambodia's other major trading partners 
added to imported inflation. Third, there were signs that the domestic economy was beginning to 
overheat in 2007. Tentative evidence indicates that aggregate domestic demand was beginning 
to significantly diverge from its potential growth path in part fueled by very high growth in 
commercial bank lending [Figure A5.1 (iii) and (iv)]. Broad money grew at 61% year-on-year in 
December 2007 due to large capital inflows, and credit to the private sector expanded at a 
record level of 76%. Credit growth to the private sector has moderated, expanding by 35% from 
January to July 2008.  
 
5.  Responding to increasing inflationary pressure, the Government announced a policy 
package in April 2008. On the monetary side, the National Bank of Cambodia would double 
banks’ reserve requirements from 8% to 16%, facilitate banks with strong finances to invest 
abroad, strengthen supervision, and provide guidelines to reduce bank lending to high-risk 
sectors, especially real estate. On the fiscal side, the Government will maintain the balance of 
the national budget as stated in the Public Financial Management Law and Reform Program. At 
the same time, the Government will try its best to increase its deposits in the banking system 
and mobilize revenue more than budgeted. Consideration is also given to reducing import tariffs 
on basic goods while balancing the loss revenue against increased taxes on luxury goods. The 
package also includes other measures, such as: (i) fixing indirect taxes to hold down the 
domestic price of petrol, (ii) providing a financing provision for the rice industry to increase 
production, (iii) reducing government consumption of fuel and electricity, (iv) lifting an import ban 
on pork, (v) suspending the 1% minimum tax on the garment industry to finance increases in

Under  the  current  dollarized  economy,  maintaining  a  prudent  fiscal  stance  is  essential  to 
moderating inflation pressures. A clear target to limit the overall budget deficit to around 1% of

7.  Fiscal policy has remained prudent and has tightened in recent years. The overall deficit 
narrowed significantly from over 7.0% in 2002 to 2.7% 2007 (Table A9), with the improvement 
reflected  in  the  current  balance  (i.e.,  current  expenditures  less  current  revenues).  The 
Government made a substantial progress in mobilizing revenue in 2007. Tax collection was up 
2.2% of GDP from 8.0% in 2006, owing to improved tax administration, increased trade volume, 
and continued strong economic growth. Indirect tax and international tax collection were up by 
0.9 and 0.7%, respectively. With routine expenditures contained, the current budget surplus was 
also higher than budgeted (3.2% versus 1.2% budgeted), indicating prudent fiscal policy. As in 
the past years, overall deficit in Cambodia remains negative at 2.8% of GDP due to the large 
capital expenditure needs (around 6.0% of GDP). The deficit is more than financed by foreign 
aid, which tends to be stable around 4.5–5% of GDP. Net domestic financing is generally 
negative and has tended to widen, reflecting the Government’s efforts to tighten policies by 
increasing government deposits in the National Bank of Cambodia. Relative to the actual fiscal 
position in 2007, the planned 2008 budget is slightly expansionary in that it projects an increase 
in the overall budget deficit and a reduction in the current surplus. This arises from lower 
projected revenues at 10.2% of the GDP, which is lower than the actual revenue of 12.1% in 
2007, and not from an expansion in spending, which is projected to remain constant at 14.2%. 
This reflects both a conservative stance of the Government in budget preparation and weakness 
in revenue projections.

9.  Issue 1: Increased Tax Revenues for Sustainable Priority Spending. Cambodia’s tax 
revenue ratio is still low compared with other countries at similar stages of development (Figure 
A5.2). Increasing fiscal revenue over the medium term will be necessary to meet the country’s 
expenditure needs. The Government’s expenditure policy aims to improve public services and 
to  increase  investment.  Currently,  as  capital  expenditure  has  been  largely  financed  by

improve service delivery and to discourage corruption, the Government has also recognized the

fiduciary risk in the use and management of public funds was high. As a consequence, the 
Government developed and began implementing a medium-term public financial management 
reform program (PFMRP) from 2004–2015, supported by development partners. The PFMRP 
aims to complete the full modernation of Cambodia’s public financial management system by

implementing  the  Government’s  development  strategy,  (ii)  introducing  effective  financial 
accountability, (iii) improving the links of priorities and service targets to budget planning and 
implementation, and (iv) holding budget managers accountable. The PFMRP includes both 
institutional  and  policy  reforms  to  modernize  the  public  finance  management  system  in 
Cambodia. At the same time, it will also address the medium-term challenges to improve 
revenue collections. Significant progress has been made in the last 2 years, including through 
the introduction of the new chart of accounts and program budgets in priority sectors. Authorities 
have  also  begun  to  advance  cash  management  reforms  that  should  significantly  improve 
expenditure  efficiency.  Much  remains  to  be  done,  however,  particularly  in  rationalizing

11.  Issue  3:  Debt  Sustainability.  With continued fiscal prudence and strong economic

1.  Key Issues  
 
The impressive economic growth over the last decade has raised living standards and reduced the poverty headcount 
in Cambodia. Per capita income has almost doubled from around $300 in 2002 to $600 in 2007. With an increased

C.  Poverty Impact Analysis for Policy-Based Lending  
 
Private sector development and growth is crucial for sustained poverty reduction, as it will be the major generator of 
jobs and incomes in the future. This is particularly true in Cambodia, where almost 50% of the population is under the 
20 years old and more than 85% of employment is in informal activities (mainly subsistence agriculture). Removing 
regulatory constraints and uncertainties hindering private sector investment and creating new businesses is crucial. 
Regulatory compliance and transaction costs, which are more burdensome on SMEs, have constrained dynamic 
growth of SMEs by keeping most of them unregistered. The Government has made progress in the areas of business 
registration, trade facilitation, and private sector access to finance, but further reforms in key areas are needed to 
strengthen the business environment. 
 
The staff study to evaluate the benefits of the proposed reforms using a general equilibrium model for Cambodia’s 
economy suggests a significant gain in the medium term. The combined welfare effects of an average 50% cut in 
transaction costs (informal) and a 50% across-the-board deduction in the effective rates of tariff are about 2.4% of the 
gross domestic product (GDP) over the medium term. The proposed reforms would also generate about 5% additional

Sector Competitiveness.  
 
2.  The objectives of the TA are threefold: (i) to support the Ministry of Commerce (MOC); 
Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy (MIME); and Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) in 
implementing and monitoring the impact of key policy reforms; (ii) to broaden and deepen the 
investment and trade policy and facilitation reform agenda; and (iii) to assist with strengthening 
capacity of the Executing Agency (EA) and implementing agencies (IAs) to produce sector 
policies. The scope of the TA parallels the PED Program, covering principally the non-sanitary 
and -phytosanitary standard (SPS)-related triggers and milestones for subprogram 2.  
 
3.  The challenge for the Government is to accelerate the creation of productive jobs to 
sustain Cambodia’s already remarkable reduction in poverty—a difficult task with as much as 
50% of the population under the age of 20 years and over 85% of employment in the informal 
sector.  Key  to  sustaining  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  is  the  expansion  and 
diversification of the private sector. With such expansion, Cambodia can benefit from greater 
integration with neighboring economies, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), 
and the rest of the world. Recent surveys and several value-chain studies identify weaknesses 
in Cambodia’s investment climate and trade regime that are impeding the country from realizing 
its potential. These include regulatory uncertainty and excessive red tape, remaining distortions 
in  the  trade  regime,  costly  trade  facilitation,  inadequate  SPS  management  systems, 
anticompetitive and informal practices, and limited access to technology and innovations. Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff estimates suggest that lowering the transaction costs of doing 
business and trading by half could add $200 million to the economy over the medium term.  
 
4.  The TA supports a core element of the Government’s private sector reform agenda. 
Under  the PED  Program,  the  Government  is  committed  to  lowering  transaction  costs  and 
improving certainty for investors. It established a sector-wide approach to mainstream trade in 
economic policy and sketched out a medium-term strategy as articulated in its diagnostic trade 
integration  study.  These  include  regulatory  reform,  trade  policy  reforms,  enhancing  trade 
facilitation  through  customs  reforms,  and  strengthening  SPS  management  systems.  The 
Government  is  also  increasing  its  efforts  to  complete  implementation  of  its  World  Trade 
Organization  (WTO)  accession  commitments,  which  will  influence  the  way  in  which  the 
Government conducts trade policy over the medium term. In this regard, MOC has established 
the  WTO  Department  responsible  for  ensuring  consistency  between  domestic  policy  and 
obligations made under WTO accession, and notifying WTO of tariff barriers to trade and SPSs 
that may affect trade. This TA also complements other activities of other development partners, 
including the Australian Agency for International Development, European Commission, German 
Agency for Technical Cooperation, United Nations Development Programme, United Nations 
Industrial  Development  Organization,  United  States  Agency  for  International  Development, 
World  Bank,  and  World  Health  Organization.  ADB  has  worked  closely  with  development 
partners in preparing the TA and will continue to do so during implementation to ensure efficient 
use of resources.

72  Appendix 9 
B.  The Technical Assistance 
1.  Impact and Outcome 
5.   The TA will support the PED Program by (i) providing the Government with assistance to 
implement key policy measures under the cluster; (ii) providing timely economic policy analysis 
and advice on trade policy formulation, trade facilitation, competition policy, and technology 
policy; and (iii) strengthening the Government’s institutional capacity to deepen the private 
sector reform agenda.  
 
6.  The impacts of the TA are an improved business climate that will reduce business 
transaction costs and help to expand and diversify the private sector and exports, contribute to 
higher  economic  growth,  create  jobs,  and  reduce  poverty  targeted  under  Cambodia’s 
Millennium Development Goals.   
 
2.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The key TA activities are divided into five components: 
 
(i)  Component 1: Trade and competition policy capacity development. The IA 
will be MOC. This component will support trade policy capacity development at 
MOC, including assisting in capacity development at the new WTO Department 
(e.g., developing internal procedures for notification, preparation for WTO’s TPR, 
trade policy analysis, procurement of equipment), developing trade remedies at 
MOC,  and  supporting  development  and  adoption  of  a  competition  policy 
framework.  The  component  will  include  a  series  of  case  studies  on 
anticompetitive practices in sectors believed to have them and proposing reform 
measures. The component will also include training staff at MOC and relevant 
line ministries on competition policy issues and will oversee the rollout of the 
enterprise registry to selected provinces. 
(ii)  Component 2: Develop and implement RIA action plans. The IAs will be 
MOC; MIME; and the Economic, Social Affairs and Culture Observation Unit 
(OBSESS). This component will support MOC and MIME to implement action 
plans for regulatory review and to strengthen OBSESS’s capacity in this area. 
Activities include utilizing a management change expert to develop a suitable RIA 
implementation  strategy,  providing  training  on  toolkits,  and  assisting  with 
developing  RIA  internal  guidelines.  This  component’s  activities  at  OBSESS 
include. staff training on RIA and toolkits and developing IT system for archiving 
laws and regulations, ,.  
(iii)  Component 3: Access to technology. The IA will be MIME. This component 
will  assist  MIME  to  develop  a  technology  policy  framework  that  will  trigger 
implementation of the technology matching grants project in subprogram 2. 
 (iv)  Component 4: Investment incentives. The IA will be MEF. This component will 
support  MEF  in  enhancing  the  investment  incentives  regime  and  protection 
through designing frameworks for double taxation agreements and advocating 
their adoption as part of the Government’s investment regime.  
(v)  Component  5:  Customs  reforms.  The  IA  will  be  the  Customs  &  Excise 
Department at MEF. This component will work with the department to strengthen 
capacity of the risk management unit (e.g., provide training on risk analysis) and 
undertake a study on Cambodia’s readiness to join the Kyoto Convention.

9.  MOC will be the EA for the TA. The TA will commence on or about 1 March 2009, and
